story:
The Story So Far

It's been almost a year since I decided to head to London on a creative adventure.

I wanted to know what I would find within myself creatively, post-motherhood, shooting on the quirky streets of London. And so I asked you - my friends, family and Indiegogo benefactors - to help me get there.

The campaign was a success! I raised enough for at least a few months in London, plus money to send postcards and prints to everyone who donated.


I'm happy to say that the project - and my whole life - blossomed into more than I ever imagined.

What I found in my street photography has been very exciting to me personally and I continue to explore the streets of London and other cities and towns in England.

I also found love and a new life here and plan to eventually settle in England with my lovely partner.


I have spent the last year in England shooting this project while on a tourist visa, which means that I have been unable to work and have relied on the generosity of friends and family to get by. This includes the money that you and others so kindly donated last year through Indiegogo, and for that I give many thanks!


The Plan

I will be having an exhibit of my street photography at Alley Cat Gallery in San Francisco during the second half of September and I am back on Indiegogo to ask for your help.

Printing and framing for a show can be very expensive, so I have decided not to frame the photos and will instead make large poster-size prints as well as smaller prints that can be displayed in grids and rows. This will keep the cost down, and also make for a dynamic presentation of the images.

This money will also cover the costs of printing and shipping prints to you, my Indiegogo benefactors. Be sure to have a look at the perks I am offering in exchange for your donations!

Thank you for your kind and generous support!
story_txt:
The Story So Far

It's been almost a year since I decided to head to London on a creative adventure.  

I wanted to know what I would find within myself creatively, post-motherhood, shooting on the quirky streets of London. And so I asked you - my friends, family and Indiegogo benefactors - to help me get there.


The campaign was a success! I raised enough for at least a few months in London, plus money to send postcards and prints to everyone who donated.



I'm happy to say that the project - and my whole life - blossomed into more than I ever imagined.

What I found in my street photography has been very exciting to me personally and I continue to explore the streets of London and other cities and towns in England.


I also found love and a new life here and plan to eventually settle in England with my lovely partner.



I have spent the last year in England shooting this project while on a tourist visa, which means that I have been unable to work and have relied on the generosity of friends and family to get by. This includes the money that you and others so kindly donated last year through Indiegogo, and for that I give many thanks!

The Plan

I will be having an exhibit of my street photography at Alley Cat Gallery in San Francisco during the second half of September and I am back on Indiegogo to ask for your help. 


Printing and framing for a show can be very expensive, so I have decided not to frame the photos and will instead make large poster-size prints as well as smaller prints that can be displayed in grids and rows. This will keep the cost down, and also make for a dynamic presentation of the images.


This money will also cover the costs of printing and shipping prints to you, my Indiegogo benefactors. Be sure to have a look at the perks I am offering in exchange for your donations!


Thank you for your kind and generous support!

story:
Just another book about breast cancer. Didn’t I already donate to one of those? How many of these things are out there?!

DID YOU KNOW?

1. There are women with breast cancer who are shunned from their families after being  diagnosed due their cultural belief that breast cancer is a punishment from God due to a woman’s sinfulness.

2. Some women hide their breast cancer from family and friends for years after being diagnosed due to fear that knowledge will hinder their career?

3. There are people who are unaware of what mastectomies look like and react offensively and negatively when seeing a woman who has had one?  Maybe you knew that. But did you know you could help change that?

4. These women are sharing these experiences, and more, with you in Bosom Buddies?

I understand why you may feel hesitant to support this book. Times are tough, Sallie Mae keeps calling you at work, and a big part of you thinks this book exists already. But as a photographer, I can assure you that you can have 100 photographers in the same place, photographing the same subject, and each photo captured from a different angle and time reveals a new insight, a new idea, and a new perspective. 


As a breast survivor, I can also tell you that perspective is every thing.  Sally, one of the photographed survivors, wants to share with you the importance of perspective to her:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nuuerkLOK28

This book isn’t about me or even the photographed survivors. It’s not about any person. It’s about a movement. It’s about shifting from seeing and treating breast cancer like it’s one-dimensional and a uniform experience.

SOME OF OUR GOALS

·  Help loved ones of someone with breast cancer understand her battle more and how to efficiently support and understand her

·  Help address the scary questions, “Even if I survive breast cancer…what will I look like, what will I be like?”

·  Change how women with breast cancer and society perceive women with mastectomies

·  Encourage women who feel ostracized by their disease to join the sisterhood of women with breast cancer

·  Provide an understanding to the misunderstood

·  Uplift and educate women that breast cancer is not a death sentence

The Gloria Gemma Breast Cancer Foundation is a huge support system for me, some of the photographed survivors, and thousands of women across Rhode Island. It has a family atmosphere where hugs are plentiful and emotions are never judged. They are there to help all people who are living with breast cancer, which includes patients, survivors, family members, and friends. Because of the amazing work this foundation does, 50% of all the profits that come from the sale of Bosom Buddies will be donated to them so that they continue their great work. 

The $10,000 will cover for the printing and the distribution for 800 books.  For the past months, I have been paying everything out of pocket and I can’t fund this project on my own anymore. A movement is impossible by one person, so please join us and contribute to the movement.

story:
The Details

Hi, my name is Mandy-Lyn. I’m a photographer and deejay from east Vancouver, Canada. I shoot all my photographs with a 35mm film camera and Kodak 400 film. My photos look to captivate the wild, free spirited nature of rock n roll and the charm and total magic of the female form though it’s imperishable sexuality. My erotic analog portraits have been an ongoing self funded series over the last five years. 

Play will be my first collected book of nude portraits. This crowd-sourcing campaign will fund the expense of producing the book as well as a limited ‘First Edition’ that will be available to sponsors of the project.

Of my most recent press, In May 2014 I shared a photo exhibition at Known Gallery in Los Angeles with fellow photographer Teen Witch (Andrea Sonnenberg) where I exhibited 50 collected portraits of my incredible female friends, shot over the past seven years. I collaborated with Altamont Apparel on a tee-shirt collection called Rock N Roll Suicides (Spring 2015); four tributes to legendary Rockers with exciting young women as the muse. Prior to that I directed and filmed a video short called Malibu for HUF Worldwide in a tribute to Sharon Tate’s performance in 1966’s Don’t Make Waves - 12 California girls on a trampoline on the shore of Malibu beach.
My portraits have been featured in publications such as Juxtapoz, VICE, Color Magazine, POSI+TIVE, Dazed & Confused, DiCE, Vogue Italia, Sad Magazine and ION. 
See me shooting some photographs for an editorial in Color Magazine here.
See my Altamont interview with Patrick O'Dell here.

Play is an intimate, super-natural experience with female sexuality. Sprung from some long conversations with a close friend and feminist author Mish Way (who will write the introduction), the idea developed through a print feature shoot for Penthouse Magazine: sun soaked analog nudes played through the spectacular untouched environments of the Pacific Northwest Coast. From ocean to river, from mountain to forest to field, Play brings the viewer on a nymph’s adventure to the most natural spaces; places of peace, comfort, joy and timelessness. 

By sponsoring this project you are doing far more than simply helping me to make a book. You’re supporting my artistic endeavour totally; helping me to fulfill a dream of seeing and sharing positive and empowering sexual content with a growing community of viewers. The hope that is carried in the heart of Play is for a healthier social review of sexual equality and freedom. 

Explore my photographs at Mandy-Lyn.com!

What I Need & What You Get

35mm film 50 rolls of film at $8.33 p/roll = $416
Polaroid film 20x10 at $200 = $200
Processing + clean up 50 rolls at $22.28 p/roll = $1114
Hi res scans 250 photos at $3 p/photo = $750
= $2480.00

Locations (fees & rentals) July & August = $4200
Transportation gas, etc. = $400
Production including design = $1300
Incentives perks and shipping = $1600
= $7500.00

Total: $9980.00
If I don't reach my goal, Indiegogo will take a 9% fee. 
If I do reach my goal, Indiegogo will take a 4% fee.

And the goodies?
Perks include postcards, signed and limited edition posters, cassette mixtapes, exclusive updates and invitations, credits and dedications in book and online, limited edition zines, original polaroids, signed and limited edition copies of the book and more! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute, you can still help a lot! Help me get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. You can use Indiegogo's convenient share tools to let your friends and social network know about Play!

story:
Be part of the IPA Photography Asia Awards 2013 & support our 1st ever crowdfunding effort.

History & Introduction

Invisible Photographer Asia (IPA) was founded in 2010, and since then has grown into a leading and influential platform for Photography and Arts in Asia. We participate vigorously in the movement of Photography in Asia through talent showcases, events and exhibitions, workshops and education, and community outreach. Since inauguration, IPA has partnered with organizations such as PLATFORM.SG, National Museum Of Singapore, The Angkor Photo Festival, KL Photo Awards to name a few.

IPA website: http://invisiblephotographer.asia

We have produced 2 annual editions of the highly regarded and successful IPA Street Photography Asia Contest. The Free-to-Enter contest was funded independently by us, with 2 prizes sponsored by friends. Last year, we received over 5,000 picture submissions. We have had 2 prize winners – a photographer from India in 2011, and from Bangladesh in 2012. Contest finalists and other winners have come from all over Asia.

This year, we will expand our contest efforts to include more categories, in what will become the inaugural IPA Photography Asia Awards. It is our goal to keep this photo awards contest accessible and free to enter for photographers from all parts of Asia. Help us achieve this goal by being part of the IPA Photography Asia Awards 2013!

What We Need

To help us achieve our goals with the inaugural IPA Photography Asia Awards, we have decided to embark on this fundraising campaign, our first ever. Here are the details:

  • Help us reach our funding Goal of USD$6,800.
  • Less Indiegogo & any transaction fees, 75% of the net funds will go towards Awards Prize money, 25% will go towards resources required to produce and facilitate the awards itself.
  • If we do not reach our funding goal, the awards will still go ahead, albiet scaled down from our initial plans.
  • We welcome any support from individuals, organisations or corporates.

The Inaugural IPA Photography Asia Awards

The inaugural IPA Photography Asia Awards 2013 will take place sometime between April to August 2013. The exact dates will be confirmed and announced at a later date.

[Updated 15.01.13] The IPA Photography Asia Awards 2013 will comprise of the following main awards categories: 1) Street Photography Asia Category; 2) Photo Essay Asia Category; and 3) Photo Book Asia Category. Category Prizes and submission details will be confirmed and announced at a later date, after our funding period.

Entry to the Contest will be FREE.

The 3 categories in the IPA Photography Asia Awards 2013 will be judged by a volunteer panel of experts invited by IPA, to be confirmed at a later date. Our previous street photography contest judges include Kevin WY Lee, founder of IPA, Ying Tang, China and InPublic's David Gibson, UK.

Previous 1st Place Winners of our Street Photography Contests include Jashim Salam, Bangladesh (2012) and Karan Vaid, India (2011). 

The final awards details, including categories and contest criteria/details, is subject to ammendment and confirmation, at the discretion of IPA.

View more information on our past contests: http://invisiblephotographer.asia/tag/ipa-street-photography-contest/

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute funds, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • If you're a photographer, you can also support us by donating a print as a perk for our Gold and Prime Sponsors.
  • We would love for you to get the word out and make some noise about our funding effort and the IPA Photography Asia Awards 2013.
  • You can easily share the news about our efforts using social tools provided right here on Indiegogo.

And that’s all there is to it.

Donated Prints for Gold & Prime Sponsorship 

Photography Prints have been kindly donated as perks for Gold and Prime Sponsorships by the following photographers:

  • Andri Tambunan, Indonesia
  • Aik Beng Chia, Singapore
  • Aujin Rew, South Korea
  • Callan Tham, Singapore
  • Derrick Choo, Singapore
  • Junku Nishimura, Japan
  • Karulos Naga, Indonesia
  • Karan Vaid, India
  • Kevin WY Lee, Singapore
  • Lim Weixiang, Singapore
  • Luis Liwanag, Philippines
  • Maika Elan, Vietnam
  • Jes Aznar, Philippines
  • Rony Zakaria, Indonesia
  • Sebastian Song, Singapore
  • Weilun Chong, Singapore
  • Tay Kay Chin, Singapore

Prime Sponsors, in sequential order, will have 1st opportunity to select their preferred choice of print. Gold Sponsors will be given prints selected by IPA, subject to availability.

Testimonials & Quotes

"As a partner with Invisible Photographer Asia for the past year, we have witnessed first-hand the commitment and drive by IPA to push Asian photography to a new height. Their programs are thoughtful and necessary. We hope you will support them"
- Tay Kay Chin, Co-founder, PLATFORM (Singapore)

"Invisible Photographer Asia is very much a serious platform at the forefront of witnessing and supporting Asian photography. It not only showcases the enthusiasm and seriousness of photographers in Asia, but also highlights the healthy camaraderie that is prevalent in the region."
- Jes Aznar, Photojournalist (Philippines)

"This is a very important project for us and the scene of Asia photography."
- Junku Nishimura, Photographer (Japan)

"There are many, many great international initiatives by other excellent organisations and folks. Our focus, and the focus of this awards, is Asia."
- Kevin WY Lee, Founder (IPA)

"There will never be a shortage of talented and passionate photographers in Asia. However, often their voice doesn't get the spotlight it deserves. Invisible Photographer Asia provides a public platform for photographers living and working in Asia to share their visions, experiences, and realities to a wide audience. Beyond photography, I support IPA because through that process, we could gain not only insights and inspirations but also a mutual understanding that brings us closer as people regardless of our backgrounds."
- Andri Tambunan, Photojournalist (Indonesia)

"In two short years, Invisible Photographer Asia has become a leading - if not the leading - online force for pan-Asian street photography and visual journalism."
- fototazo.com

"Online photography platform Invisible Photographer Asia is giving street photography in Asia a newfound visibility and buzz"
- CNN.Com

For Further Information

IPA Website: http://invisiblephotographer.asia/

IPA Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/invisiblephotographer

IPA Twitter: https://twitter.com/InvisPhotogAsia

story:
Short Summary

Did you know that testicular cancer kills more men under the age of 30 than women with breast cancer? My hope is that this project educates the world about the leading cancer of men ages 15 - 35.  I want to give HOPE and RECOGNITION to all victims and survivors of testicular cancer. The Sneakers Book Project will do just that... give HOPE and RECOGNITION to these great men by funding research initiatives to testicular cancer. If you would like to purchase an art book, go to http://store.carlosjonesonline.net

 

The Impact

Everyday a man is diagnosed with testicular cancer.  If treated and detected early, testicular cancer victims are often cured.  You can make a difference in a young man's life today with your contribution. The ultimate path to reduce the death rate from testicular cancer is through awareness and early detection.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and SHARE! SHARE! SHARE! Please inform everyone you are connected with about this project. Not too many people know about this disease, yet so many men die EVERYDAY from testicular cancer. 

Check out the share tools that Indiegogo has set up to make as easy as humanly possible - Facebook, Twitter, etc. all at the click of a mouse.

If you are interested in purchasing the book for the project, please go to http://store.carlosjonesonline.net

story:
"Project: In Disposables" is a worldwide photography project.

"Project: In Disposables" is something I wanted to start after seeing so many budding, as well as established, photographers on tumblr and flickr, many of them located all around the world.

Give and Get.

Any funds received from this campaign will be used directly to purchase, ship and develop the disposable cameras.

As far as perks, I am offering friendly emails, typewritten letters, random prints or a spot in a special "contributors" round will be available to any conrtibutors (up to 10/MUST BE IN U.S.) who donate $15.00.

And if you can't contribute, spreading the word and giving the project site a visit will have just as much of an impact.

Thank you,

Jeremy Myers

 

Here are some of the photos from the first round cameras:

Any funds received from this campaign will be used directly to purchase, ship and develop the disposable cameras.
As far as perks, I am offering friendly emails, typewritten letters, random prints or a spot in a special "contributors" round will be available to any conrtibutors (up to 10/MUST BE IN U.S.) who donate $15.00.
And if you can't contribute, spreading the word and giving the project site a visit will have just as much of an impact.
Thank you,
Jeremy Myers
 
Here are some of the photos from the first round cameras:

story:
About the Project

In 170 pages of vivid and engaging photography, Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings documents the physical and emotional devastation suffered when two bombs exploded at the 2013 Boston Marathon, killing three people and injuring more than 260. It's a story of homegrown terrorism, the upending of Bostonians’ sense of safety, and a  community’s memorializing of the event and its victims. Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings ultimately tells a story of the value of community and the triumph of the human spirit.

Greetings! I'm Joshua Touster, a professional freelance photographer documenting this world of ours through my camera lens. Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings is a photographic journey through the makeshift memorials, the lockdown, the crime scenes, and the Red Sox victory parade. The book documents the first anniversary of the bombings, the two subsequent Boston Marathons, One Boston Day, the trial of perpetrator Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, and the construction of permanent memorials to the victims. 

The book begins with my introductory essay and Boston Globe reporter David Abel's eyewitness account of the moment when the bombs exploded. It concludes with an in-depth chronology of all relevant events.

This project was personal. I live in Watertown, Massachusetts, one of central locations in the midst of the unfolding events, and Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings is my take on the aftermath of the bombings and my community’s coming to grips with them.

Documenting this piece of Boston history isn’t just about Boston. It’s much larger than that. The terror that took place is part of our new reality, one which has played out in so many cities around the world. By focusing on the local, this project is a microcosm of the global experience of terrorism.

Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings is an intense and emotional photographic journey of the two-and-a-half year period following the bombings at the 2013 Boston Marathon. 

We Need Your Support: Let's Raise $55,000

You are invited to become part of this important effort by contributing to the Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings project. This is a story that should not be forgotten:

"Tragedies that fade quietly into history are bound to be repeated."

I wish to disseminate this important photographic document to as many people as possible. Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings serves as both an historical testament to that fateful day and an impetus for thoughtful conversation about the lessons of terrorism.


What Will $55,000 Pay For?

This is an important project. Your generous donations will help place this book in thousands of public libraries; high school, middle school, college and university libraries; historical societies, and other public institutions throughout Massachusetts. And if we surpass our goal, the reach of the book's distribution will extend to institutions beyond Massachusetts.

Your gift will also help place copies in the hands of those directly affected  by the tragedy: the victims’ families, the survivors, the hospitals that cared for the injured, and the police and fire departments that played a central role in saving lives.

Perks for Contributing

As a thank you for helping achieve this worthy goal, you are entitled to some terrific perks like signed prints and copies of the book. But most importantly, you are sharing a story of great importance, so that future generations will experience for themselves this pivotal moment in our history.

Thank you so much for supporting the Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings project. Your donations help to educate and to heal so that tragedies like this may not be repeated.

Spread the Word

To help make—and hopefully surpass—our goal, we need to reach as many people as possible.

Please help by forwarding this appeal to anyone and everyone you know, and ask them to share with all of their contacts as well:

• Use the Indiegogo share tools at the top upper left of this page to let everyone know about Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings project.

• Copy these links into your Facebook page and other social media sites:
www.bostonmarathonaftermath.com  
www.igg.me/at/bostonmarathonaftermath

• Send these links to everyone you know:
 www.bostonmarathonaftermath.com 
www.igg.me/at/bostonmarathonaftermath

About the Author

Joshua Touster received his first camera at the age of four, and when he was 11 he turned the bathroom in his family's New York City apartment into his first darkroom.

Since then, he received his MFA in photography from the Rhode Island School of Design, was on tour with Michael Jackson for seven weeks, and spent numerous seasons photographing the Los Angeles Lakers, the New England Patriots and the Boston Red Sox. He has shot absolutely everywhere there is to photograph at a bevy of Boston area hospitals (especially Mass General), taught photography at many institutions including Wellesley College, Curry College, and the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, photographed in more clubs, concert halls, and outdoor festivals then he could possibly remember, lectured about his work in prisons and universities, photographed thousands of weddings, bar mitzvahs, and corporate events, and shot for both profit and non-profits clients ranging from Harvard University to the Union of Concerned Scientists to IBM.

He has shown his work in numerous solo and group exhibitions both nationally and internationally. He received an artist-in-residency grant from Yaddo in Saratoga Springs, and spent an entire season photographing the minor league baseball team the Brockton Rox (“We even came within one inning of winning the championship!”) which resulted in his book A Season On The Rox. He has photographed ballet dancers, artists, athletes, and politicians, toured on and off for five years with the band Phish, documented the Occupy Movement in both Boston and on Wall Street, and spent six years knee-deep in the world of horse racing at Suffolk Downs Race Track and Saratoga Race Course. 

Aftermath: The Boston Marathon Bombings is a culmination of two-and-a-half years of engaging work about a tragic event, the strength of the human spirit and the essential nature of community.

Josh is constantly photographing his family, friends, and almost everything he comes in contact with (since he almost always carries a camera with him!) He responds with empathy and great joy to the people, places, and events around him, capturing light, movement, weather, and his own unique insights into humanity and this crazy world of ours.

www.bostonmarathonaftermath.com
www.igg.me/at/bostonmarathonaftermath

story:
Ever since I first laid eyes on photos taken from a recreational drone, I've been completely captivated with the unexplored possibilities.  After saving up and convincing myself the purchase would be worth the investment, I took the leap and acquired a DJI Phantom 4 drone.  The first time I sent this small robot four hundred feet into the air and looked through the view on my phone, I felt a swarm of butterflies in my stomach.  It was a mix of excitement at the astonishing view, with a dash of fear resulting from this expensive piece of equipment I just purchased soaring across the sky.  I knew immediately that I wanted to share these views with as many people as possible.  I created an Instagram page to share my favorite shots.  I went out every weekend to explore a new state park with my robot companion in tow.   I printed out the 80 page study guide provided by the Federal Aviation Administration and got to work on prepping for my unmanned pilots license.  Now six months later I've gathered a reasonable sized following, built up a portfolio of content, passed my FAA exam  (which allows me to fly for the sake of making money), and booked my first revenue while shooting for a real-estate construction story by a local newspaper.  That video was showcased to over a thousand community leaders at a local event.  

 

  • I'm asking for $2500 to help push me to the next level.   Essentially, the equipment is just really expensive.  I need another drone (not only for specific use cases, but a backup in case of technological difficulties is a must), I need multiple extra batteries, a carrying backpack would be nice...  I need to purchase full insurance coverage and get some legal help with that.  If I'm going to make it in the industry, I need to stay at the forefront of technological advances. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Not surprisingly, I won't be the first drone media company in the city of Columbus.  At the time of this writing, there are two other competitors to my knowledge.  While competition is scary, it also validates the market.  There's money to be had in this business, and I know that I'm producing the best content.  Of course, producing the best content doesn't necessarily yield guaranteed success, but I'm confident in my chances. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, there's still plenty of ways you can help. Spreading the word and sharing my content is always appreciated.  If you know anyone who might want or need some drone shoots, I'd love for you to send them my way.  Thanks so much for any and all help!

story:
The story

I have traveled the Iranian Kavir deserts for more than 10 years now. Every time I am on my way back, I am looking forward to return soon. We got to know each other little by little. Something I appreciate about desert’s nature is its silence and awesome magnitude. Its beauty leaves the spectator awestruck. There is nothing tame about its aesthetics. Rather, it is interweaved with dichotomies: life and death, heat and cold, drought and humidity, light and shadow. The persistent drought will not bow to the human presence and the tranquility swallows his need for attention. It is dangerous, sensual and oblivious of the human categories of meaning and mind. To deliver this sensation, my photographs play with form, structure, lines, contrasts and grey scales.  

After all these years of taking photographs, I am grateful to see that this passion project has received attention by international photography awards (e.g. IPA, New York) and was exhibited in Germany and Iran. To be invited to Venice during the Venice Biennale 2019 is an important step for me and the development of this project. It is a unique opportunity to introduce "Shadows of Silence" to a wider international art audience. 

As you saw in the video, my minimalist photographs are in black/white as, in my opinion, this is the best way to capture the essence, atmosphere and our own introspection of nature. I use digitale as well as analogue photography techniques. Since I am asked this very often: no, I do not edit my photographs. No collages, no artificial lightning, no tools - just my camera and me in the desert. 

If you are interested in this and my other projects, please feel free to visit my website: www.basim.ir, instagram: @basim_ghomorlou, facebook: Basim Ghomorlou.

Your support matters

In the meantime, I'd be grateful for your support. This exhibition is is a game changer for me and so is your contribution. Tell your friends and fellow art enthusiasts. If you have questions regarding this campaign or the perks, just let me know and I am happy to help. Thank you very much! 

I will keep you updated. Talk to you soon!

Basim
